front: What does 'semantic' mean in the context of HTML?
back:
In HTML, 'semantic' refers to the meaning that an element conveys. Semantic elements describe their purpose or content clearly (e.g.,

for paragraphs).

front: How is writing an HTML document similar to writing a text document?
back: Both use structure and formatting like headings, paragraphs, images, and emphasis to organize and present content meaningfully.

front:
What is the semantic meaning of the

element?
back: It represents a paragraph of text.

front: Which commonly used HTML element does NOT have semantic meaning?
back: The <div> element. It is a generic container without inherent meaning.

front: Why is semantic HTML important for accessibility?
back: It helps assistive technologies like screen readers interpret the page structure and content more accurately, improving usability.

front: How can semantic HTML improve SEO?
back: Search engines can better understand and index your content when semantic elements are used, potentially improving search rankings.

front: How does semantic HTML help developers?
back: It makes code easier to read and maintain. For example, you can edit a <nav> element directly rather than searching through generic <div>s.

front: What are three benefits of using semantic HTML?
back: Improved accessibility, better SEO, and clearer, more maintainable code for developers.

front: What is the most important aspect of creating structural hierarchy in HTML?
back: The correct use of heading elements (h1–h6) in a meaningful order that reflects the structure of your content.

front: What does the number in an <h1> to <h6> tag represent?
back: The heading level, with <h1> being the highest (top-level) and <h6> the lowest.

front: How many <h1> elements should a page typically have?
back: Usually only one. It should represent the main title and come before all other content.

front:
Is this heading structure valid?

Main

Section

Another Section
back: Yes. Multiple headings of the same level (e.g., <h2>) are allowed and common when organizing sections.

front:
Is this heading structure valid?

Main

Subsection

Section
back: No. You should not skip heading levels. <h3> should not come before <h2>.

front: Should heading elements be used just to style large text?
back: No. Use headings only for structure. Use CSS to control visual size and styling.

front: Why is proper heading order important for accessibility?
back: Screen readers rely on heading structure to navigate content. Skipping levels (e.g., <h1> to <h3>) can confuse users.

front: How does structural hierarchy affect SEO?
back: Search engines use heading structure to understand and rank content. Malformed structure can reduce visibility in results.

front: What happens if HTML heading structure is incorrect?
back: Your HTML might be invalid. The browser will guess how to display it, which could produce unintended results.

front: What’s the best way to style headings without affecting structural hierarchy?
back: Use appropriate heading tags for structure, and apply visual styles using CSS instead of choosing headings for their size.

front: What is the main difference between presentational and semantic HTML?
back: Presentational HTML focuses on appearance and styling, while semantic HTML describes the meaning and structure of content.

front: Why is presentational HTML discouraged in modern web development?
back: It harms accessibility, is harder to maintain, and separates content from styling less effectively than using CSS.

front: What does it mean when an HTML element is 'deprecated'?
back: It means the element is outdated, no longer recommended, and may be removed in future HTML specifications.

front: What does the <font> element do, and why shouldn't you use it?
back: It changes font size and color. It’s deprecated—use CSS instead for styling text.

front: What does the <center> element do, and what's the alternative?
back: It centers content horizontally. It's deprecated—use CSS (e.g., text-align: center) instead.

front: What does the <big> element do, and why is it deprecated?
back: It increases font size relative to surrounding text. It's deprecated—font size should be set with CSS.

front: What are some examples of semantic HTML elements?
back: <header>, <nav>, <section>, <figure> — these describe the role of the content within them.

front: How does semantic HTML improve accessibility?
back: It helps screen readers understand the structure and purpose of content, improving navigation and usability.

front: How does semantic HTML benefit search engines?
back: Semantic elements help search engines interpret and index your content accurately, improving SEO.

front: Complete the sentence: Presentational HTML focuses on appearance, while semantic HTML...
back: ...describes the meaning and purpose of the content.

front: What was the original purpose of the <i> element in HTML?
back: To display text in italics for visual presentation.

front: What is the modern, semantic use of the <i> (idiomatic) element?
back: To mark text that is different in voice or mood, such as idioms, thoughts, foreign phrases, or technical terms.

front: What attribute can be used with the <i> element to specify a language?
back: The 'lang' attribute, e.g., je ne sais quoi.

front: What is the purpose of the <em> (emphasis) element in HTML?
back: To mark text that should be emphasized compared to surrounding content. It affects meaning, not just style.

front: How is the <em> element typically displayed in browsers?
back: Browsers usually render it in italics to visually emphasize the word or phrase.

front: What is the difference in meaning between <i> and <em>?
back: <i> indicates a shift in voice or mood without implying importance, while <em> emphasizes importance or meaning.

front: Should <i> or <em> be used for purely visual italics?
back: No. If text is italic only for style and has no semantic meaning, you should use CSS instead.

front: Which element would you use to emphasize the word 'your' in: 'Never give up on your dreams'?
back: Use your to emphasize the word and convey importance in the sentence.

front: What type of text is best suited for the <i> tag?
back: Text with a different tone, foreign phrases, or technical/idiomatic terms that don’t convey emphasis or importance.

front: What is the purpose of the <b> (bring attention to) element?
back: To visually highlight text without adding semantic importance. Commonly used for keywords, product names, or standout terms.

front: How do browsers typically render the <b> element?
back: Browsers usually display <b> content in boldface to visually draw attention.

front: When should you use the <b> element?
back: When you want to highlight text without implying urgency or importance, such as product names or terms in summaries.

front: What is the purpose of the <strong> element?
back: To indicate that text is of strong importance, urgency, or seriousness. It adds semantic weight.

front: How is the <strong> element typically displayed in browsers?
back: It is displayed in boldface, similar to <b>, but carries semantic meaning.

front: What is the key difference between <b> and <strong>?
back: <b> adds visual emphasis without meaning, while <strong> conveys importance or urgency in the content.

front: Which element would you use to label a warning or alert?
back: Use to signal the urgency or importance of the message, e.g., Warning: Contains allergens.

front: Can <b> and <strong> look the same visually?
back: Yes, both default to bold styling, but only <strong> communicates semantic importance to screen readers and search engines.

front: How do you decide between using <b> or <strong>?
back: Use <b> for non-urgent visual emphasis; use <strong> when conveying critical importance or warnings.

front: What is the main purpose of a description list in HTML?
back: To present terms and their corresponding details, like definitions or descriptions, in an organized format.

front: Which HTML element wraps a description list?
back: <dl> — the description list element, which contains all terms and details.

front: What does the <dt> element represent in a description list?
back: A description term — usually a word, phrase, or item being described.

front: What does the <dd> element represent in a description list?
back: A description detail — the definition or value associated with the preceding <dt> term.

front:
Is this structure valid?
<dl><dt>Flour</dt><dd>2 cups</dd></dl>
back: Yes. 'Flour' is the term and '2 cups' is the related detail — this is a valid description list entry.

front: Can description lists be used for things other than definitions?
back: Yes! They're useful for recipes, FAQs, product specs, contact info, and any key–value pair data.

front: How are items typically styled in a description list by default?
back: The <dt> term is aligned left, and the <dd> detail is slightly indented to the right.

front: How many <dt> and <dd> pairs can a single <dl> contain?
back: As many as needed — you can repeat <dt> and <dd> pairs throughout the same <dl>.

front: What type of data pattern is best suited for description lists?
back: Any key–value pair format where one item labels the other (e.g., term-definition, item-quantity, question-answer).

front: Why might you choose a description list over other list types?
back: Because it semantically links a label to its associated detail, which is useful for accessibility and meaning.

front: What is the purpose of the <blockquote> element in HTML?
back: To represent an extended quotation from another source, usually displayed as an indented block.

front: How do you attribute a source in a <blockquote> element?
back: Using the cite attribute (e.g., cite="https://example.com") to specify the URL of the source.

front: Does the cite attribute change how a <blockquote> looks in the browser?
back: No. It doesn't affect the visual presentation but provides metadata for screen readers and search engines.

front: How do you display multiple paragraphs inside a <blockquote>?
back:

element inside the

element.

front: What is the <cite> element used for?
back: To visually mark the title of a referenced work, such as a book, article, or film.

front: What's the difference between the <cite> element and the cite attribute?
back: <cite> is an element used for visible source titles; cite is an attribute used for hidden source metadata.

front: What is the purpose of the <q> element in HTML?
back: To mark a short, inline quotation within a paragraph. Browsers usually add quotation marks automatically.

front: Can the <q> element use the cite attribute?
back: Yes. It works like in <blockquote>—providing source metadata without affecting appearance.

front: What’s the main difference between <blockquote> and <q>?
back: <blockquote> is for long, standalone quotations. <q> is for short quotes within paragraphs.

front: When should you use a <blockquote> instead of a <q>?
back: Use <blockquote> for longer, multi-line or multi-paragraph quotes. Use <q> for brief, inline quotations.

front: What is the difference between an abbreviation and an acronym?
back: An abbreviation is a shortened form of a word (e.g., 'Dr.'), while an acronym is formed from the first letters of a phrase (e.g., HTML = HyperText Markup Language).

front: Which HTML element should you use to mark up abbreviations or acronyms?
back: The <abbr> element.

front: What does the <abbr> element do?
back: It semantically marks text as an abbreviation or acronym, and optionally provides a full description via the title attribute.

front: How do you display the full meaning of an abbreviation using HTML?
back: Use the title attribute in the <abbr> element. For example: <abbr title="HyperText Markup Language">HTML</abbr>.

front: How does the title attribute in <abbr> affect user experience?
back: It allows users to see a tooltip with the full form of the abbreviation when they hover over it.

front: Does the <abbr> element always change the appearance of the text?
back: No. It may be styled differently depending on the browser, but by default it often looks like normal text unless the title attribute is added.

front: Should you use <abbr> for every abbreviation on a page?
back: Not necessarily. Use it when the abbreviation might be unclear or when it benefits from additional context.

front: What is an example of using <abbr> to mark an acronym?
back: <abbr title="HyperText Markup Language">HTML</abbr>

front: What visual cue might browsers add to an <abbr> with a title attribute?
back: Some browsers show a dotted underline or display small caps, along with a tooltip on hover.

front: Why should you use the <abbr> element for acronyms like HTML or CSS?
back: It provides semantic meaning, improves accessibility, and helps users understand abbreviations with tooltips.

front: What is the purpose of the <address> element in HTML?
back: To semantically represent contact information for a person, company, or organization on a web page.

front: Why should you use the <address> element instead of a <div> for contact info?
back: Because <address> is a semantic element that clearly defines the content's purpose, improving accessibility and SEO.

front: What types of information are typically included inside an <address> element?
back: Physical addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, and names or titles of people or organizations.

front:
What does the
element do in an address block?
back: It creates a line break, often used to format street, city, and country on separate lines.

front: How do you create a clickable phone number link in HTML?
back: Use Phone to allow supported devices to initiate a call.

front: How do you create a clickable email link in HTML?
back: Use Email to open a user's default email client.

front: What are some potential drawbacks of using mailto links?
back: They can be perceived as spam and may attract email-harvesting bots if not protected.

front: Is <address> limited to physical mailing addresses only?
back: No. It can also include phone numbers, email addresses, names, and even links to contact forms.

front: In what types of pages or sections is <address> most appropriate?
back: Contact pages, author info blocks, footers, or any section with contact-related content.

front: What is the purpose of the <time> element in HTML?
back: To represent a specific time, date, or both in a way that's understandable by both humans and machines.

front: What attribute must be used with the <time> element to provide machine-readable data?
back: The datetime attribute.

front: Why is the datetime attribute important?
back: It makes the date or time machine-readable, improving SEO and helping browsers understand the timing details.

front: What format should the datetime attribute use?
back: The ISO 8601 format (e.g., 2024-06-15T15:00 for June 15, 2024 at 3:00 PM).

front: What does the 'T' represent in the ISO datetime format?
back: It separates the date and time portions in the datetime value.

front: How would you mark up a time value of 8:00 PM using the <time> element?
back: <time datetime="20:00">20:00</time>

front: How do you mark up an event date of June 15, 2024 at 3:00 PM using the <time> element?
back: <time datetime="2024-06-15T15:00">June 15</time>

front: What types of content should use the <time> element?
back: Use it for events, appointment times, article publication dates, deadlines, or any timestamped data.

front: Does the <time> element affect how text is displayed by default?
back: No, but it adds semantic meaning and enables machine processing of the time data.

front: What does the <sup> element do in HTML?
back: It renders text as superscript — raised above the normal line and smaller in size.

front: What are common use cases for the <sup> (superscript) element?
back: Exponents (e.g., 2<sup>2</sup>), ordinal numbers (e.g., 1<sup>st</sup>), and superior lettering for abbreviations.

front: When should you use the <sup> element instead of styling with CSS?
back: Only when the superscript conveys semantic meaning, like exponents or proper typographical formatting.

front: What is an example of using <sup> for a math equation?
back: 22 (2 squared) is 4.

front: What does the <sub> element do in HTML?
back: It renders text as subscript — lowered below the normal line and smaller in size.

front: What are common use cases for the <sub> (subscript) element?
back: Chemical formulas (e.g., CO<sub>2</sub>), footnotes, and mathematical variable subscripts.

front: What is an example of a chemical formula using <sub>?
back:
CO2

— for carbon dioxide.

front: Should you use <sup> or <sub> for visual styling alone?
back: No. If you're only adjusting appearance, use CSS instead of semantic tags.

front: What does superior lettering mean, and how is it marked in HTML?
back: It refers to abbreviated letters in superscript (e.g., M<sup>gr</sup> for Monseigneur).

front: What is the purpose of the <code> element in HTML?
back: To represent short, inline snippets of computer code within text.

front: What default styling is applied to the <code> element in most browsers?
back: Text inside <code> is displayed in a monospaced (fixed-width) font.

front: What type of code is best suited for the <code> element?
back: Short, inline code snippets such as property names, function names, or commands.

front: How would you mark up this code in HTML: color: blue;
back: color: blue;

front: What is the purpose of the <pre> element in HTML?
back: To preserve whitespace and formatting, allowing display of multi-line preformatted text.

front: How do you display a multi-line code snippet in HTML?

block to preserve indentation and formatting.

front: What happens to indentation and spacing inside a <pre> element?
back: It is preserved exactly as written in the HTML source.

front: Should you use <code> alone for long code blocks?
back: No. For long code, use <code> inside a <pre> element to preserve formatting.

front:
What is a good use case for 
...
?
back: Displaying code samples or examples in technical articles and documentation.

front:
Why use semantic elements like and 
 instead of just 
?
back: They add meaning, improve accessibility, and allow consistent styling and formatting for code.

front: What is the purpose of the <u> element in HTML?
back: To indicate text with non-textual annotation, such as misspellings or proper names with special markings.

front: What is the default browser styling for the <u> element?
back: A black underline beneath the text.

front: Should you use the <u> element for styling underlined text?
back: No. Use CSS for styling instead; <u> should only be used for semantic purposes.

front: What is the semantic use case for the <s> element?
back: To mark text that is no longer accurate or relevant, such as outdated information or cancelled events.

front: What is an example of <s> in use?
back: <s>Tomorrow's hike will be meeting at noon.</s>

front: What elements should be used instead of <s> to show document edits?
back: <del> for deleted text and <ins> for inserted text.

front: What is the <ruby> element used for?
back: To display small annotations above or below text, commonly used for East Asian pronunciation guides.

front: What does the <rt> element represent inside a <ruby> element?
back: It provides the ruby text, such as pronunciation or translation details.

front: What does the <rp> element do in a ruby annotation?
back: It provides fallback parentheses for browsers that do not support ruby annotations.

front: What is a common use case for the <ruby> element?
back: Showing pronunciation guides for East Asian characters in educational or multilingual documents.
